DIV1.P: The Choleric Fathers. A COMIC OPERA. PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for G. G. J. and J. ROBINSON, Pater-noster-row. M.DCC.LXXXV.

DIV1.HEAD: THE CHOLERIC FATHERS. A COMIC OPERA.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE I. After the OVERTURE, the Curtain rises and discovers a grand Serenade before the House of Don Julio Pimiento, and under Donna Zelida's window.

SP.L: THOU restless God that lov'st to hold
Thy vigils where Zelida dwells,
With peaceful sleep the fair enfold;
From starts and tremors, charms and spells,
From goblin, guard her, elf and sprite,
Which prying haunt defenceless night
With eye too free and hand too bold.
Oh happy! happy! let her dream
Of some most sweet celestial theme,
While Sylphs glide smiling by, and starry meteors gleam.
With music charm her ravish'd ears,
Such and so heav'nly as the spheres
Of old to wond'ring sages play'd:
These varied joys, oh love, decree,
Worthy her and worthy thee,
To nightly sooth th' angelic maid.

DIV2.STAGE: The Musicians retire, and Jaquelina enters from the street door.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Well this is charming! This serenading, and these raptures and love—I do believe all the young Dons in Madrid are dying for my mistress—Such sweet music, and every night and all night long the same—one goes to ep so happy, and has such delightful dreams!—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fabio on the opposite side.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ah, my sweet and gentle chambermaid! Of all persons in the world, you are the very person I was the most desirous to see.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Why then, my most spruce and politic serving∣man, you have only to open your eyes—And having seen, pray what is the nature of your very pressing bu∣siness?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: An embassy of high import: I am Love's pleni∣po. Here is a letter from my master to your mistress: I don't know the contents; but I am sure they must be delicious. Are not you of my opinion?
SP.STAGE: [Gives her the letter in one hand, and money in the other.]

SP.SPEAKER: Jab.
SP.P: Hum! partly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Oh, Don Fernando writes in a very masterly stile on these occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Pretty well, pretty well; but do you know that I was myself coming in search of that sweet face of your's?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Indeed! and what say you to my face?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Hum! I cannot say much in its praise.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Nor much in its dispraise, I flatter myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: You do indeed—but go, run away with your face as fast you can, and tell your master Don Fernando to wheedle his father into a good humour, and bring him here as quick as possible, for that our old Don is at present disposed to treat with him concerning this said marriage of their children.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: He is a good deal alarmed at our nightly concerts, and wishes to see Zelida safely married.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Good!

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Overtures have been made by Don Velasco in behalf of his son Don Fabricio; but in consideration of my mistress's preference of your master, of his fa∣ther's great wealth, and of the still greater pains I have taken to persuade him in favor of Don Fernando, why—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: We shall carry the day, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Perhaps—You know the grudge these two tetchy old fathers bear one another—they are for ever disputing, fonder of their opinions than they are of their children, and your master has no occasion to be told how necessary caution and expedition will be in this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: My dear delicate little dormouse, your voice is sweeter than the nightingale's, and your words more re∣viving than cherry-brandy. This intelligence will be worth a quarter's wages to me at least; but you are a divine little Angel, that's the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I'll swear it.—Oh, apropos, my dear Jaque∣lina, I had almost forgot to tell you how devilishly I am in love with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Desperately! I though to have mentioned it the last time I saw you, but some how or other the thing escaped my memory—Indeed, one has so many affairs on hand, one cannot think of every thing; I recollected it before I had got a dozen yards from the door, but then it was too late: so I tied a knot in my handkerchief, as you see, to remind me the next time I met you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: That was extremely kind of you. And really, you are a—tolerably—impudent—agreeable fellow.—Pray—where did you lay in all that large asortment of assurance?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: By a long intercourse with people of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: There I believe you are mistaken, Mr. Fabio. You footmen have not learnt your agreeable assurance by imitating your betters, but your betters have learnt theirs by imitating you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Upon my honor, my dear, I believe you are right; footmen and kept-mistresses lead the ton.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Fabio, I must be gone and deliver your letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: You'll remember what I have said to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: I'll tie a knot in my handkerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ay, do, do.

LG.L: I'll certainly do my endeavor,
Dear Sir,
To remember your handkerchief favor,
Dear Sir;
I shan't want the wit to get out of your debt
Nor can I forget
That you're most prodigiously clever,
Dear Sir.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Your shape, air, and gait, are so striking.
Dear Sir;
What damsel but must take a liking,
Dear Sir!
Turn about, Sir; look there! how genteel, debonnaire;
Well, I vow and declare!
Oh dear, you're prodigiously striking,
Dear Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Now will I go in search of—who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Still, one of us I see.—And how has fortune be∣haved to thee since I saw thee last?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: As she generally behaves to men of merit—very ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: True—I am a living proof of her injustice.—Had she treated me according to my deserts—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Thou had'st been hang'd long ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What, still aiming at wit—wilt thou never learn a little common sense? The way to thrive, is, not to persuade thysels, but others, that they are witty.—What hast thou got in that brown paper parcel?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: My whole estate, real and personal.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What, all?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: All; these few reals exepted [holding out his hand] with which I am going to purchase—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: A good lining—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: To a bad outside.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: No matter for that.—He that wants me, may find me, any time these two hours, at the three Jolly Friars.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What, thou art in want of a place?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Why no; don't I tell thee I have not spent all my money?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: It's a great pity my master has got Don Pimiento's consent to marry his daughter. Thou hast an excellent turn for intrigue, and I might have helped thee to em∣ployment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ay, it's a damn'd shame fathers should be so reasonable and compliant—But no matter—I desy Fortune with all her crew of obstinate relations, called Fates and Destinies—When one spoke of the wheel is up, another must be down—The road of life is very hilly—full of ups and downs.

LG.L: Of ups and downs we daily see
Examples most surprising!
The High and Low, of each degree,
Now falling are, now rising:
Some up, some down, some in, some out;
Some neither one nor t'other:
Knaves, Fools, Jews, Gentiles, join the ou
And jostle one another;
With my heigho!
Gee-up! gee-ho!
Higgledy piggledy!
Truth, Honour, Honesty!
Trim tram!
Your Honesty's scarce,
Honour's grown a meer farce,
And poor Truth! baw! an obsolete Whim-wham.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: By ups and downs some folks, they say,
Among grandees have got, sir;
Altho' they were but yesterday
The Lord knows who, or what, sir!
Sans sense, or pence, in Merit's chair
They doze and dream supine-o!
But how the devil they came there—
That neither you nor I know.
With my heigho! &c.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Your country maid comes up to town,
A simple, aukward body,
In half a year again goes down,
No peacock half so gaudy!
Lord, ma'am! exclaims the lawyer's wife,
With scandal ever ready,
You see the ups and downs of life
Have made our Meg a lady!
With my heigho! &c.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Virtue and Vanity lately are grown
Mere buckets in a well, sir;
The last gets up, the first gets down,
As all the world can tell, sir.
So many downs poor Virtue meets,
Her ups so very few, sir,
Tis said she's naked met i'th' streets,
But that is nothing new, sir,
With my heigho! &c.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Oh! what an age of ups and downs!
Hey! seven's the main, my lord thrice knocks;
And lands and liberties, manors and towns
Are rattling in the dice-box!
Up fly the fools! on ruin bent,
While they are full in feather;
Get pluck'd, then rumbling down are sent
Whoop! pell-mell! all together.
With my heigho! &c.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fernando, and his Father Don Salvador.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Be certain, sir, your com∣pliance in this particular would ensure my everlasting gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: But I tell you Don Pimiento is a passionate, positive, captious—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Nay, but hear me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: A pretended Philosopher! A head so full, of whims! So tenacious of his opinions—I hate to see any man tenacious of his opinions—No, no; I am fully convinced he is a weak, silly, wrong-headed old Lord, and I am certain all the arguments in the world will never persuade me to the contrary.

DIV2.STAGE: [During this speech, Fabio takes Fernando up the Stage and whispers him.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: My dear father, I have just received a message from Donna Zelida. She informs me, her father is con∣senting to our union, and wishes to see both you and me. Surely, sir, you will not refuse—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Don Pimiento wishes to see me, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Well; well; that being the case, I can have no objection to the daughter.

DIV2.STAGE: [Exeunt into the house of Don Julio Pimiento.
SCENE changes to the museum of Don Julio Pimiento.
Zelida in a morning dress, and Jaquelina meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Return'd so soon, Jaquelina!

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: I met Don Fernando's man, Fabio, at the door, madam, he gave me this.

DIV2.STAGE: [Delivering a letter, which Zelida opens and hastily reads.]

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Um—um—Well!—Um—um—um—um—very well!—But did you deliver my message?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Oh, yes, madam, and you need not doubt but Don Fernando will soon be here.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: I need not question his love and diligence. I am certain of his affection and sincerity; or, whatever it might cost me, I would not indulge the sweet sensa∣tions, the raptures I feel at his remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, madam, love—love is a most delicious thing—And tho' these men fellows are sometimes in their airs, and are proud and cross, and un∣constant; yet they are sometimes so loving, and so sweet, and so fond, that one cannot help liking them with all their faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: This kind compliance of my father, to our union, will make me love him, if possible, better than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: But why, madam, sorry or pleas'd, vex'd of glad, do you always sigh?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: A sigh, Jaquelina, is the constant and first effusion of a feeling heart.

LG.L: When adverse to love we stern destiny find,
And our pangs have no hope of relief,
Despair haunts each thought, languor seizes the mind,
And we sigh with th' excess of our grief.
Or when, by kind fortune, revers'd is our lot,
And sorrows no longer annoy,
Again the tear flows when the terror's forgot,
And we sigh with th' excess of our joy.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Julio Pimiento and Fernando.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Your consent, sir, makes me the happiest of men, and my heart assures me I shall become the most affectionate, the most constant, the tenderest of husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I hope so; Zelida deserves the most affec∣tionate and tenderest of husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Deserves! Oh, yes, sir, she deserves more than the world has to give.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Tho' I partly approve your transports, young gentleman, you must moderate your ecstacies. Let' philosophy teach you to govern your passions.—I had once as much fire and rhodornontade as you, or any hot∣brain'd Don in Spain. I was obliged to steal my wife, my Zelida's mother. I tried every kind of stratagem to get at her, but finding none of them were successful, I set fire to the house, and carried my mistress off thro' the midst of the flames.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Ay, sir, that was a lover's philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But go and pay your mistress a morning visit: you have no objection, I suppose. Your father and I will settle preliminaries.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am sure, sir, they will be to our satisfacti∣on. (With hesitation.) But, excuse a lover's fear—Let me beg, let me conjure you, sir, to avoid every tenden∣cy to contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Ay, ay: make yourself perfectly easy; do not fear my discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: My father, sir, has his oddities—apt to laugh, yet every body allows him to possess noble senti∣ments, and a generous heart—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I am as willing as any man to do justice to the good qualities of others—Don Salvador is a gentle∣man and a Spaniard.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Somewhat too passionate, I confess—And then—sir—your temper being—a little—hasty.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Hasty! I hasty!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: That is—sir—having—a little—generous warmth in your temper.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Warmth, young gentleman! What do you mean by warmth? No man has more philosophy—No man can be more cool, more candid, more open to con∣viction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I own it, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Yes; but he is damn'd loth to own it tho'.—As for your father, his positive obstinacy is be∣come proverbial.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I allow, sir, he has a predilection for his own opinions. Let me therefore once more-intreat—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pim.
SP.P: 'Pshaw! Don't I tell you, I am prepared to overlook his improprieties—These modest hints, this ad∣vice, so adroitly insinuated, is all superfluous to me, and should have been bestowed at home, upon your father.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, sir, I have your promise; on that I will depend.

LG.L: Around the spacious landscape rove,
The Naiad's haunt, the Triton's bed;
Search ev'ry grot and ev'ry grove,
Where art and nature beauties shed.
Whate'er is rich, whate'er is rare,
Whate'er is worthiest to be known,
Collect from sea, from earth, and air,
From fossil, plant, or precious stone.
While wonders then with wonders vie,
And latent miracles dispense;
While this attracts the raptur'd eye,
And that allures the ravish'd sense:
Attentive, while the busy sage,
Delighted, marks the boundless store,
Exulting, swells the learn'd page
With secrets, unobserv'd before.
Oh come, in all thy native grace,
Zelida, come, and bless the view;
And ev'ry former wondrous trace
Shall vanish, like the morning dew.

SP.P: This is likely to be an important day. The mar∣riage of my daughter, and the termination of my law∣suit with the house of Cordova!—If justice takes place, I cannot lose it—And yet I have my fears—The Count has great power at court—Yet, where right is so evi∣dent, they will not dare do wrong.

DIV2.STAGE: [Goes and sats him∣self at his library table, on which are various papers, ma∣thematical instruments, crucibles, phials, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Good morning, Don Pimiento.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Good morning, good morning, Don Salva∣dor. I have lately made some very curious experiments, by which I find the ponderosity of light, or, to speak more philosophically, the levity of light is extreme! All Spain by no means contains a pound.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What do you laugh at, Don Salvador? I say the experiment is a very curious experiment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Who doubts it? Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Then what do you laugh at, Don Salvador?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Laugh at? To think what a devilish dear commodity light is in England!—Well, here you are, like Noah in the ark, surrounded by all your birds, beasts, infects, and reptiles—Ha, ha, ha! Philosophy must be a plaguy expensive plaything.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Plaything, sir! Plaything, Don Salvador!—Let me advise you as a friend, Don Salvador, when∣ever you speak of philosophy, to do it with more re∣spect, lest you should incur reproof from the learned and the wise—Philosophy, Don Salvador, philosophy is a Being of a superior and divine nature; whose head is among the stars, her feet in the bottomless deep, and whose eye penetrates matter, form, and infinite space, even to darkness and nonentity.—
SP.STAGE: [As the Scene ad∣vances, the laugh of Don Salvador becomes and increases in∣to a laugh of vexation restrained.]

P.HI: Ha, ha, ha! I always told you it was some∣thing monstrous.—A divine nature! Philosophy, Sir, is a dissector of grubs, a painter of shadows—she was born in amazement with her mouth open, has fed upon maggots, and peers, and pores, till she fancies she finds miracles stuff'd in the cavity of a mite's cranium, or hid in the hair of a flea's foot.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Permit me to tell you, Don Salvador, philo∣sophy is a thing totally beyond your comprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha ha!—ha, ha! yes, and yours too.—Our present business, Don Pimiento, is the conclusion of our children's marriage. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: It is so, it is so—and, as I have promised your son Don Fernando to be cautious, I shall take care to avoid all altercation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Which promise, if kept, will redound very much to the honor of your understanding, Don Julio Pi∣miento. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do you mean to insinuate any thing to t discredit of my understanding, Don Salvador?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! I insinuate nothing, Don Pimi∣ento.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Or, that I am not circumspect in my con∣duct?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, I affirm no man is less captious.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: You are a very worthy gentleman, Don Pimi∣ento, but very choleric. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Choleric! I choleric!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Were you as dispassionate, as ready to listen to reason as I am—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: You!—dispassionate!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Tow dipp'd in tar, will not catch fire so sud∣denly, or blaze out so furiously.—Oil, brandy, and Phlo∣giston are not so inflammable.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—ha, ha!—You are describing yourself, Don Pimiento, not me.—My temper, like a deep stream, flows on smooth and unruffled.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Smooth! You, Don Salvador! Flow!—Pardon me, but yours is an electic fluid, all flame!—How∣ever, be under no constraint; emit your sparks; discharge yourself; I am a philosopher, and do not fear a shock.—Be you as captious as you please; I shall be cool! cauti∣ously cook.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! I perceive, Don Pimiento, how remarkably you are disposed to coolness and caution.

P.HI: What do you mean by that, Don Salvador? Am I not cool? Am I not cautious? Is it posible for any man to be more so?
Ha, ha, ha, ha! Well, well; where are our children?
Am I not cool, Don Salvador?
Exceedingly; as cool as you were the other day, when I laughed because you asserted heat was no∣thing.
Sir, you may laugh again if you please, and I will assert again, and will assert in the face of the whole world, that heat is not a thing, but a quality.
Ha, ha, ha, ha! And so you still persist in affirming, that the blaze of a faggot, or the light of a candle, is nothing?
Sir, I affirm no such thing.
And that were I to burn my finger, or scald my leg, I should feel no pain?
I say, sir, pain is a sensation, produced by the reaction—
And if my house was burnt to the ground, you would pretend it was still standing.
Sir, the reaction—
Or that the fiery lava of Mount Vesuvius, while it sweeps away fields, flocks, men, and cities, is totally innocent, has nothing pernicious in its effects.
Sir, the reaction— (very loud, and very angry) Sir, I say no such thing.
Then what do you say, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, you won't hear what I say, sir, you can't understand what I say, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: That is your fault, sir, for not speaking in∣telligibly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do you mean to call me a fool, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I have too much respect to good man∣ners to follow your example.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do you mean to say, sir, I don't know good manners?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I mean to say, sir, you don't practice 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, your son shall have no daughter of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, both you and your daughter would be too much honor'd in the alliance.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Too much honor'd! Jaquelina! Diego! Who waits there?—Zelida!—Somebody call my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: My dear father, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Come here, child, come away from that—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: What, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: My dear father, what is the occasion of all this warmth?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I would sooner marry my daughter to a de∣scendant of the Cyclops, or the great grandson of Cacus, than to the offspring of such a passionate, perverse,—Bu I despise—

P.HI: My dear sir, pray for Heav'n's sake forbear.
What can have occasioned—
Here has he been asserting again that fire won't burn, that water can't quench it, that Mahomet's black ram was an Alderney cow, and that the man in the moon wears a Harle∣quin's jacket.
Sir, I asserted no such things; I despise both buffoonery and buffoons.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Despise! Do you despise me, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.STAGE: (Getting between them and forcing him off)
SP.P: Pray sir, consder, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, I despise ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, you are,—
SP.STAGE: (Zelida puts her hand over her father's mouth.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, no man shall dare despise—

SP.SPEAKER: Don. Fer.
SP.STAGE: (Raising his voice to overpower his father's, nd forcing him out.)
SP.P: Be pacified, dear fir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I'll suffer no blockhead—

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, dear, dear sir, be ool.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Cool—I am here with the determination be cool—I have given my promise to be cool; never my life was more circumspect! never! never!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Let me beg you, sir, to walk this way.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: An obstinate, hot—I'll send to Don Ve∣sco, instantly! instantly!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Pray, sir—

STAGE.HI: (Partly coaxes and partly drags im off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: So, there's an end of that business, and the lo∣rs may get at each other if they can.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Ah, Jaquelina!

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Ah, madam! I told you how it would be.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: My father is going to send for Don Ve∣lasco; if he comes, I am ruined. Don Pimiento will pledge his word, and no power on earth then will be able to shake him.—Run, fly, Jaquelina, intercept the mes∣sage, invent some means—

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Ah, it's too late, madam, here is Don Velasco himself.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Vel.
SP.P: Good morning, Donna Zelida. Is Don Pi∣miento within?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: No, sir; he is just gone out. (Turning round) Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don Velasco, I am happy to see you! You are the very person I was going to send to. Zelida, go to your own chamber, and don't stir from thence, nor see any person whatsoever without my knowledge. (Exit Zelida.) Do you follow your mistress, and see that I'm obeyed.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: The Devil take philosophy, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Vel.
SP.P: You seem a little disturbed, Don Pimiento.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I should have been, Don Velasco, if I had not more than a common command over my passions.—I have been assaulted by an Ignoramus, insulted by a sneering Idiot, and I am very happy you are come.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Vel.
SP.P: Well, Don Pimiento, which way can I—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I believe, Don Velasco, you recollect you did me the honor to hint that an alliance between our sa∣milies would not be disagreeable to you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Vel.
SP.P: It is what I very ardently desire, Don Pi∣miento.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I am happy to hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Vel.
SP.P: Your daughter is a young lady of such win∣ning manners, of so mild, so amiable, so sweet a disposi∣tion, that I am fully persuaded, could my son, Don Fabricio, obtain the honor of her hand, it must make him he happiest of men; which is a thing, as you may sup∣pose, I am most anxious to see accomplish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do me the honor to walk into my cabinet. Don Velasco, we'll conclude the businesss in∣tantly.—I give you my word of honor, Don Velasco, your son Fabricio shall have her.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the street again.

LG.L: He that has not a penny in pocket, or purse,
Is sure in a happy condition,
For bankrupts and bailiffs he cares not a curse,

DIV2.P: I'll keep no more company with skinkers.

LG.L: He hickups up sorrow,
And laughs at to-morrow.

DIV2.P: Knaves that pocket their pence, and talk mor-orality—Fellows that never could discover a pimple on their nose.—Rascals that will sneak out of the world without ever beholding two o'clock in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Now must I go seck that rogue Pedro: he may become a precious implement in the present reverse of our affairs—Ah! who's that? Pedro?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The pennyless.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: You are happy, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I say you cannot see: I am only half happy—T'other cup, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Another—If you have any charity, lend me a ducat.

P.HI: Not a real.
Then go and hang yourself—If you'll give me a bottle you are a prince, if not, you are a vile compound.
A compound?
Ay, of water, abominable water and clay.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Hark thee, Pedro, I have no time to lose: Don Pimiento resuses his daughter to my master, and we are come to a determination to carry her off, either by ar∣tifice, or force of arms, in which thy assistance may be of service.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Say no more—I'm for you— [points to his fore∣head] I have it—ripe—full of expedient—liquor en∣lightens my understanding, and generates stratagem and deep reflection—Give me but another bottle, and I'll find thee out the longitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Not a drop

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Well, where is this new master of mine? or, rather, this new landlord?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Thy landlord?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Yes; my master's Palace is my Inn: the only difference is, that, instead of his bringing me in a bill, I make him provide for me first, and pay afterwards for the trouble I take to eat and drink his dainties—Nature, cer∣tainly, intended me for a statesman, but Fate took pity on me, and ordained that, instead of catering for others, others should cater for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Prithee, Pedro, what liquor in the world dost thou love best?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: What a shallow numskull of a question is that!—I love'em all best—

LG.L: Your Mountain, Sack, your Frontiniac,
Tokay, and twenty more, sir,
Your Sherry, and Perry, that make men merry,
Are Deities I adore, sir!
Your potent Port
Must praise extort,
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
The Briton, sir, John Barly-corn,
Stands highly in my favour;
His mantling head doth well adorn
His valor, and his flavor!
Nay Cyder-an,
Is a mighty man!
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
Old Rum, Arrack, and Coniac,
Are known for men of might, sir!
Nor shall Sir Flasket Florence lack
A place among my Knights, sir!
Don Calcavella
Is a noble fellow
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
Madeira! Monarch! him I sing!
And old Hock! lo! another!
Champaign is my most Christian King!
And Burgundy's his brother!
Brave Bourdeaux! too,
Shall have his due!
When from his palace forth he comes!
And glucks and gurgles! fumes and foams!
If, singly, thus, each Champion may
So many laurels gather,
Gods! what a glorious Congress they,
When all are met together!
When, high in state
Each Potentate
Forth from his spacious palace comes!
And glncks and gurgles! fumes and foams!

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the house of Isabel.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: Is there no message, no note from Don Fabricio?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: It's very strange—a mighty attentive lover!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: You know, madam, he was not to be here yet this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Isa.
SP.P: What tell ye me of half hours?—But I won't teize myself about him—I don't care if he never comes—Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Did not somebody knock?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I heard nobody, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: You are very sparing of your labour—go and see.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.STAGE: (Aside, and putting the things to rights on a table)
SP.P: I know she'll bid him begone the moment he is here; her vanity is never satissied, with him, or without him.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Why don't you go?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why Lord, madam, I am sure there is no∣body.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: What an odious colour'd ribband this is! (Unpins her breast-knot, and throws it on the table.) What a horrid dull morning!—No—he does not in∣tend to come; or, if he does, he will expect that, because one feels a partiality in his favor, one should immediately tell him so!—In direct terms!—No, indeed!

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: Wherefore tell me, silly lover,
I coquettish am, or vain?
In my looks you might discover
What my lips must not explain.
He who, when a maid denies,
Believes her words, and not her eyes,
Shall live the bye-word of the plain,
And envy some more happy swain.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Go bid the footman order my carriage—No, come back, give me my veil, I'll take a walk.
SP.STAGE: [Laura reaches the veil, and sees the breast-knot.]

P.HI: Lord, madam, why have you taken this off? This breast-knot is the very colour I heard Don Fa∣bricio praise so much yesterday.
I am glad you have told me; I'll never wear it any more—Where is my veil?
Here, madam.
And why don't you give me the breast-knot?
Did not you say, madam?—
I never saw so stupid a creature! (Lau∣ra gives her the breast-knot, and offers to throw the veil over her mistress.) What is the girl about?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Lord, madam, I declare there is no such thing as pleasing you unce you have been in love. I never knew a person so altered in my life; you are neither atis∣fied with your lover, nor yourself, nor your servants, nor any one thing about you. I am sure, ma'am, for all I am cross'd in love, if the defect of it was not very different upon me, we should soon part; but it makes me all pati∣ence, meekness, and good nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Thee! Why, art thou in love?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why should I not, madam? Do you think I have not a heart in my bosom as well as your ladyship?—I am sure many a sigh has my fond passion cost me.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Sigh! and fond passion!—I shall detest the words as long as I live.

P.HI: Humph! Sugar's sugar, tho' a body be a ser∣vant—And a handsome young fellow's company and kisses are as sweet to us as to our betters.

LG.L: My Sancho was the dearest youth!
My joy, my only treasure!
Love's blessings dwelt around his mouth!
His eyes spoke peace and pleasure!
Tho' suns should scorch, or frosts should bite,
Did dearest Sancho chear me,
I'd sing by day and watch by night,
Rejoic'd that he were near me!
For Sancho, &c.
So sweetly on his pipe he'd play!
Oh! how I lov'd to hear him!
As jocund he, as blith as May!
'Twas heav'nly to be near him!
Oh! Sancho, &c.

DIV2.STAGE: [While the Song is singing, Isabel retires into an inner apartment.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Oh, here comes her lover; now she may vent her cross, cankerbitten humours upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: How the girl stands! Why don't you fly to the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Lord, madam, the footmen have no∣thing else to do.
SP.STAGE: [Isabel goes to the glass, looks at herself, and adjusts her breast-knot.]

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Fabricio. [Runs up eagerly to Isabel.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: My Isabel! My life!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Where have you been? Why did you not come sooner? Or, why did you come at all?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Did you wish me here sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Me wish you here!—Lord, let go my hand, and don't teize me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: How can you, Isabel, be so perverse?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Perverse! Upon my word!—You have a very happy choice of expressions.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: You know my affection, Isabel; you are sensible of my passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Indeed I am sensible of no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I declare, Isabel, there is no supporting your injustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: My injustice indeed! I find, sir, you are come, as usual, only to wrangle with me; but, I assure you, it would be much more prudent to stay at home, when you find yourself in these tempers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: To wrangle, Isabel? Is this to wrangle? No; I came to adore, to die for you, if it would give you pleasure. Tell me but which way I might contribute to your happiness, and you shall see how I will fly to execute your will.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: I beg you will rise; you can't any way con∣tribute to my happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.STAGE: (evidently very much vexed, and endeavoring to recover himself)
SP.P: This is hardly to be borne! Nothing, Isabel, but love like mine, could support your treatment.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Treatment! Pray which way have I treated you ill? And if I do, why do you come to me again? Who desires your company? Have not I told you a thousand times, I never wished to see you more?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Yes, cruel, unjust, ungrateful woman, you have; but, take care; perhaps you may tell me so once too often.

P.HI: So, so; threats too! A very pretty obe∣dient lover, to be sure, you are; and I am a very un∣just, hard-hearted, lady!
Is it in the power of man to bear your ca∣prices?
My caprices!—Insolent!
How have I deserv'd—
Well, well; lord I tell you, again, I wish you would not bring your ill humors here.
My ill humors! Did I not come with smiles in my face, and joy in my heart? hoping, for once, to have met a sweet return of those gentle trans∣ports, which I felt glowing so ardently in my own bo∣som?

Indeed, Don Fabricio, I must once more repeat to you, that if you can come here for no other purpose but to find fault with me; to tell me I am un∣just, ungrateful, capricious, and heap every other kind of aspersion upon me, you can invent; I must beg, and insist, you will never come here any more.

Very well, Isabel, very well, since I am so totally disagreeable to you, and since your commands are so very absolute, you will find I am not so pitifully abject as to be thus repeatedly and everlastingly scorn'd and repuls'd.—Yes, I will obey these your positive, your haughty commands, and perhaps with more for∣titude than you expect, perhaps more than you wish.
Wish! Indeed! I wish!

Yes, more than you wish; you cannot so disguise your wishes, but they will appear in spite of that caprice by which they are clouded; nay, had I not been well persuaded you had a partiality, and a strong one, in my favor, I should not so long have endured the injustice of your behaviour; but, while I saw it, and felt my own passion as pure, and, at least, as ardent, as yours, I hoped, vainly, I find, it might be possible to conquer that coquettish, unworthy, and dis∣stisfied humor by which you are tormented.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Pray, sir—How dare you, sir!—Be gone, sir! this instant be gone! and never presume to obtrude yourself into my presence again!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Obtrude?—Yes, haughty lady, I will be gone, and observe your injunction, punctually, literally.—Good morning.—
SP.STAGE: [Don Fabricio, going, is met by Don Fernando.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Fabricio, this is fortunate! I came pur∣posely, hoping to meet you. [Looking round, and ob∣serving the disorder of Fabricio and Donna Isabel, who has sat down] But!—You!—What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: An ungrateful—proud—passion∣ate— [bursts into tears] There is no supporting his treatment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: They have been quarrelling—He wants to break with her, no doubt, that he may be at liberty to marry Zelida.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I am determined I will be no longer the Dupe of her caprice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Yes; it is evidently so. [to Don Fabricio with an air of chagrin.] You have heard, I presume, Don Fabricio, of the treaty between your father and Don Pi∣mento?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Concerning what, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Your marriage with Donna Zelida.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I have.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: And pray give me leave to ask you, Don Fa∣bricio, what you think of that treaty?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I think it would be a very wise treaty for me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: And—and—and you consequently think, Zelida—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: An Angel! I do upon my soul, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But give me leave to observe t'ye, Don Fab∣ricio, there are prior claims.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Claims that will be ins;isted on, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I perceive you are growing angry, Don Fer∣nando; and as I am not very cool, at present, I shall bid you a good morning.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Before you go, Sir, I demand a categorical answer.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: And with that menace on your face?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: No equivocation, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Hark ye, Don Fernando, if you should meet any hot, irascible young gentleman of your acquaintance, who wants to be taught manners, pray inform him my name is Fabricio, and that I am to be found on the Prado at five.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Sir!— (Going to follow, but stops short) Perhaps I am to blame—it is evident he and Isabel have quarrell'd—I will enquire further of her—Yet why did he avoid an explanation?—The charms of my Zelida are irresistable!—She must, she shall be mine: yes, I will in∣dulge the flattering idea.

LG.L: As, lonely, thro' the mead, or grove,
Or by the limpid stream,
Of thee, Zelida! while I rove,
Indulging fancy's dream,
I hear thy voice, enchanting maid!
Thy beauteous form I feign,
Strange transports ev'ry sense invade!
And thrill thro' ev'ry vein!

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: If fancied Pleasures are so great,
And feeble Memory may,
Thus, with her phantoms, captivate!
These ecstacies convey!
If, absent, I, entranc'd, may feel
Sensations so divine!
What raptures shall that hour reveal
Which makes thee wholly mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Thou seest the effects, Fabio, of half an hour's sleep, a wet napkin, and a razor.—Now am I as fresh as if it were midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Don Fernando bade me follow him hither—Oh, here he comes.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Don Fernando, and Donna Isabel.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: What you tell me gives me a thousand fears and suspicions. I was accusing myself, while he, perhaps, was artfully exciting me to a quarrel that might serve his own purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: It is but too probable—Fabio—Oh, this, I suppose, is Pedro?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: And your humble servant, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Fabio has given me a high character of thy abilities. Hast thou considered—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The affair, I believe, stands thus, sir: Your fathers have quarrelled, are passionate and obstinate. One of them is a pretended philosopher, or rather a philoso∣phic news-monger.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: He is so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Who makes a few nick-nack experiments and listens with avidity to the discoveries of others, which he publishes as his own, in the very teeth of the person from whom he received his information.

P.HI: You have a deal of observation, Mr. Pedro?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Observation is the essence of genius, madam, and genius is not confin'd to rank.—I must get in∣troduced to Don Pimiento, as a philosopher just come from Paris or Pisa, or any other place far enough off—if I could learn what is the philosophic chit-chat, the wonder of the day—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What I can procure: I have a college ac∣quaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: An expedient must next be found to wheedle, or terrify, Don Salvador into compliance.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I can think of none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Leave that to me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: But Don Fabricio!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What of him, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Is this lady's lover, and, as we sear, has been quarrelling with her for the purpose of being at li∣berty to marry Zelida.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Then we must have some plot for him also.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But is thy brain as fertile as thou seem'st to think?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Time must determine, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, I promise thee that success, in this affair, shall make thy fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ah! sir,—he that has a heart as merry as mine—why his fortune's made.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Yes—but a little money—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh Laud!—Ay, sir—is an excellent thing!—Money!—money is the father of mirth—and mother too egad.—He that does not want money will never want relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: We will not be ungrateful, Mr. Pedro.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.L: Love's pleasures, surely, should be great,
For, ah! too frequent is the pain.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.L: Yet still, its ills to mitigate,
Our griefs find ease while we complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Lord! ma'am, Don Fabricio's gone hence in a huff!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I met him; he look'd most confoundedly gruff!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: He star'dl

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Cock'd his hat!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Twirl'd his thumbs!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Bit his lips!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: And look'd full as glum as—as—as

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The moon in eclipse!

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Love's pleasures, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE I. The street before Don Julio Pimiento's door, which shuts to.

SP.P: SO, our sham philosopher has got admittance.—I wish it were possible to see Jaquelina; but that, indeed, is not to be hop'd.—Hey! who's this? (retires a little, peeping.) By Jupiter, it is she herself!

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: I have escaped for a moment, if I could but find that—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ah, my sweet gilliflower!—This is lucky; we concluded you and your mistress were close prisoners.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: No; we are on parole, at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: And you have taken a liberty natural to your sex, especially to chambermaids, and strayed beyond your limits.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: If ever we do stray, you men are the first to tempt, and the first to reproach us.—But come, come; tell me, what does your master intend to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Hang himself, if he can't marry your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: 'Pshaw! let him marry first, he may hang himself afterwards.—But there is no time to be lost.—Has he any plan?—any—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Oh yes, an excellent one!—Despairing of meet∣ing you, my master has sent a letter to your mistress, by a philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: A philosopher!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: A pretended one, an arch fellow; one Pedro; but, unless he sees you, he may find no means of convey∣ing his letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: I must be gone then.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: No hurry—It may be some time, perhaps, besore we meet again; and you must know, Jaquelina, that ever since I told you how prodigiously I was in love with you, I have thought of nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Then your memory is vastly improved.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I really believe, if you give me encouragement, as I have no doubt you will, I shall be mad enough to marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Don't be too certain, sir; I assure you, I am very difficult to please.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Are you? why pray tell me what sort of a hus∣band you would wish?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: I would have him very patient, for I am passi∣onate, and hate contradiction; very industrious, for I don't love work, yet should chuse to have every thing decent about me; very handsome, for I must insist on having pretty children—

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ah! that I am afraid won't entirely depend upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Very brave, for I am apt to quarrel, and want a protector; then he should have some money, for I love pleasure, fine cloaths, and good living; a neat person, for I hate a sloven; a genteel appearance, for I should prefer a gentleman-like carriage; besides which, he must have understanding enough to commit no follies himselt, and to overlook all those that I commit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Well, my dear, the article of money excepted, you may find all these perfections united in me.—Indeed, I am persuaded, fate designed us for each other. For my own part, I can safely say, I am one of the cleverest fellows, and best creatures, breathing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: You are?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I am, upon my honor.—We shall be vastly happy; as the proverb says: we shall wear too heads un∣der one hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Two heads under one hat! two heads under one cap, if you please, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Nay, as you please, my dear.

P.HI: And, if I do marry, I shall not chuse too many children.—Not above a pigeons pair at the very most.
Granted.
The boy shall be monstrous clever.
Be it so.
But the girl!—The girl shall be the greatest genius, and the finest person!—That is, she shall be the very moral of me.
To be sure, my dear—I'll take particlar care about that.

She shall have a fine neck, an elegant shape, a most beautiful face, a charming leg and foot; then, as I was a saying, she shall be a monstrous great genius—She shall dance delightfully, sing divinely, play on the music like an angel, and paint like a goddess, without ever being taught.
Without ever being taught!
To be sure—Don't I tell you she is to be a genius?
Very well, my dear, she shall be just what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Yes; I expect everything is to be just as I please.

LG.L: Cold or hungry, wet or weary,
Husbands ever must be pleas'd:
Nor with saucy pout, or query,
Wives must ever once be teas'd:
Patient, humble,
Unknown to grumble,
Seldom angry, soon appeas'd;
Cold or hungry, wet or weary,
Husbands ever must be pleas'd.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Tho' of folly they're convicted,
Yet, should they the fact deny,
Wives must not be contradicted;
Nor once ask for reasons why:
Swinging, dinging,
Scolding, singing,
If they laugh, or if they cry,
Wives must not be contradicted;
Nor once ask'd for reasons why.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, Fabio, have you any intelligence? Has Pedro got admittance?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Yes, sir, and I have luckily met Jaquelina, who is now informed of our plan.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: That's fortunate! watch hereabouts 'till Pedro comes back, that, in case of any accident, you may be at hand: but keep out of sight. (Fabio retires) If this fellow should be detected, what resource shall I find next?—anxious, restless, hoping, fearing, I am uneasy and unhappy every where—Oh, Zelida!

LG.L: When gloomy thoughts my soul possess,
Alike in palace, plain or grove,
Fond sighs my griefs and pangs express;
And plaintive songs of joyless love.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: When doubts, impatient, rend my heart,
As rends the hawk the turtle-dove,
Indignant, from each wound I start;
And sing the wrongs of injur'd love.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: But should my pangs, endur'd so long,
The cruel Fates to mercy move,
I'd gladly change the mournful song;
And sweetly sing the joys of love.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, the Museum of Don Julio Pimiento.
Enter Don Julio Pimiento, and Pedro as a philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir, I have correspondents in all parts of the world. It is the business of my life to seek out men fa∣mous in philosophy; and, being at Madrid, could not neglect the opportunity of being known to a philosopher so renown'd as el noblissimo, y savantissimo, y eloquen∣tissimo, y Venerabilissimo, Don Julio Pimiento de San∣dovalo.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, from the profound respect you pay to philosophers, I can make no doubt but you are, yourself, a philosopher of the first distinction.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir, modesty always imprints her mark upon me∣rit. I shall therefore say nothing of my own abilities. I shall only hint, sir, that if you can find on the earth's circumference so deep a thinker, so just a reasoner, so a∣cute an observer, so—but, sir,—modesty—modesty for∣bids me to finish my sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: And have you travelled far, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Far? From the Arctic to the Antarctic: I have visited all countries, climates, and nations, known and unknown.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Unknown!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: U—u—un—known; yes, sir, unknown—except to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sure, sir, you—you—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I lie, he means to say—Sir, have you ever heard of air balloons?

P.HI: Somewhat, sir, but very imperfectly. I—I shall—
Sir, I'll explain that mat∣ter t'ye more fully another time.
You say you have correspondents? Can you inform me how foreign philosophers are at present employed?
Exactly. In Sweden and the North, they are making experiments; in Germany, they are mak∣ing systems; in France, they are making fortunes; and in England, they are making parachutes.
Parachutes? Pray, sir, what are they?
A parachute, sir, is a—a—mathematical in∣strument, vulgarly called an umbrella, into which if you put a cat, you may toss her from the top of a house without breaking her neck.
That you might have done before, sir—But can you toss a dog?
No, sir.
Or a sheep?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh no, sir, a cat is your only animal for a parachute—Pray, sir, are you a Mesmerite?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: A Mesmerite, sir? what is a mesmerite?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Is it possible, sir, that you should never have heard of Mesmer?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Never, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Nor Deslon?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Nor of that sublime—sublimity—animal mag∣netism?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Never, never, sir—What is it? What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Is it! Sir—It—It is—It—It—Sir—It is so—wonderful!—so—profound!—so—I—I can't tell you what it is.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Then it must be profound indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh, sir—It—Do you keep any females in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: To be sure, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I thought, sir, as a philosopher you might ex∣clude them your mansion.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Why they are but troublesome animals, I own.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh, here comes one. Young woman, stand still.
SP.STAGE: [Strips up his sleeve, takes a letter out of his pocket, puts himself in a position, and points to Jaquelina with his fore-finger, endeavouring at the same time to make her per∣ceive the letter that he holds behind his back in his other hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What are you about, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Going to magnetize this young woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Magnetize me indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Yes, young woman! Walk round that way.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do as you are bid, hussy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: That way, that way; a little more that way.

DIV2.STAGE: [Endeavouring to make her see the letter.—Jaquelina at last perceives his intention, takes the letter, reads the direction, and throws it spitefully away.]

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Um—um—um—um—um—um—What mummery is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: It is for your mistress Zelida, and so directed to avoid detection.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What? What is that? What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: This young woman is in such robust good health it will require longer time to—
SP.STAGE: [Again putting himself in an attitude; Jaquelina takes, and endea∣vours to conceal, the letter.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But what letter is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.STAGE: (Pretending to discover that Jaquelina has it.)
SP.P: Ha! young woman, how came you by this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: You just now dropped it, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: This letter, Don Pimiento!—Ah! if you knew the contents of this letter!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: To the most famous and renowned master of all sciences, Dr. Don Lilibulero. Is it cu∣rious?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir, were you to read it, you would never reco∣ver from your surprise!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: It would give me vast pleasure! Permit me to—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Pardon me, Don Pimiento, it is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What, it contains philosophic secrets I sup∣pose?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Secrets! Ay, sir, secrets that would make your hair stand on end!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: If this business succeeds, and it is at present in an excellent train, the young shall rejoice, and the old shall laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Laugh!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ay, sir, laugh!—Nay, what is more strange, shall be laugh'd at.—And to convince you, Don Pimi∣ento, of the confidence I place in you, I will venture to inform you, that this whole affair is a scheme, to make a fool of a Philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Ah!—I conceive—not a—a—a deep—You understand me—but some shallow—dabbler.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The very man.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pim?.
SP.P: To convince him of his error, and at the same time surprise the world with a discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir, if you knew the letter by rote, you could not better divine its purport. Could not you let this pretty maid step and put it into the post?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: By all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.STAGE: (Going to give it her; but turns back)
SP.P: But you'll give me your word of honor, Don Pimiento, not to en∣deavor, directly or indirectly, to come at the contents.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Such a promise is needless, sir, but I do give you my word of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Here, young woman, take it instantly, and there is ten ducats for your trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Ten ducats! Zounds! he is very liberal! This must be some rare secret indeed, that he is in possession of!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Be very careful.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Oh, don't you doubt me.
SP.STAGE: (Eyes Pedro, the dress, the ducats, the letter, &c. All the time endeavouring to restrain her laughter.)

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: Never fear, I'll take care of your letter,
I'm as cute as another; why not?
Jaquelina, no chambermaid better,
Has studied the trim of what's what.
Tho' grave your
Behaviour,
Your letter, your outlandish looks, sir,
Your ducats, which better than books are,
By half,
Your air astronomical,
All are so comical,
Excuse me! I must take my swing!
For there's no such thing
As forbearing to laugh!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: The jade! How merry the ducats have made her!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I take it for granted you have no children, Don Pimiento.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Pardon me, sir, I have a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Indeed!—Is she married?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Hum!—sorry for it—A philosopher should live as undisturb'd as the spiders in his window.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But she will be shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The sooner the better—Girls are ever in love, and then their wits are all set to work to deceive—Love letters, rope ladders, and elopements are their continual study—You are right; marry her—marry her—and to the man she loves—Let her be miserable her own way.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But I hope to see her happy, for which reason

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Fool that I am! What have I forgot?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What is the matter, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The most necessary thing in the whole process!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: What sir? What?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I beg ten million of pardons, Don Pimiento, ten million of pardons; but must instantly be gone to prepare the second part to my letter. 'Tis of the utmost conseqence! The affair can't wait a moment!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir, I would by no means intrude upon time so valuable; but, when more at leisure—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh sir, you will be certain to see me again: have not the least doubt, sir, that I can forget a Philoso∣pher so renowned as—

DIV1.HEAD: DUET.
DIV1.L: El noblissimo! y savantissimo!
Y eloquentissimo! y venerabilissimo!
Don Julio Pimiento de Sandovalo!
To whom unpeopled lands shall know
How much they owe.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Most learned, scientific sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Nay, I insist, you shall not stir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Permit me, sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: You must not stir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I beg, kind sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: You shall not stir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: If any thing new should occur—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: You shall hear of me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Be so kind as to call when you're in our vicinity.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.L: This vast honorificabilitudinity
Commands my esteem!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Any project or scheme—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir, your's is the clover—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Oh! dear sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The cream—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Kind sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.L: The virginity
Of all I discover.
I find in myself an incompossibility—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.L: Do not stir,
To express my esteem!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Learned sir, your civility!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Your admirability!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Would I had docility—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: And I volubility—

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: To express my esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Learned sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Do not stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: This vast honorisicabilitudinity
Commands my esteem!

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the house of Don Salvador.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I must request, Mr. Fabio, you will lay aside some of this familiarity, and put on a little more respect and reserve. Consider the difference between laqueys, like you, and a person of my character and consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I own, Pedro, thou, like many others, dost assume, and very naturally too, a conse∣quence to which thou hast no pretension. But come, my Philosopher, tell me what scheme thou hast next, in order to succeed with Don Salvador, as well as thou hast done with Don Pimiento?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: There are but two keys to the human heart, Hope and Fear, and this observation, friend Fabio, if thou wert not naturally very shallow, would convince thee, I am really more of a Philosopher than thou dream'st of.—Canst thou tell me what thing in this world Don Salvador fears the most?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: The inquisition.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: An attempt was once made upon him, for the sake of his wealth, by those holy fathers, which he got clear of with honor; but which gave him so much trou∣ble, and terror, that ever since, he has held the holy office, and all its implements, in utter dread and abhor∣rence. The very name of an inquisitor will make him quake like the bass-string of a harpsichord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Then I am an inquisitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Thou!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Shut thy mouth, and on with thy observations, if thou hast any thing more to communicate.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: The inquisitors being all ecclesiastics, Don Sal∣vador detests, and never fails to take his revenge on, all orders and degrees belonging to the church, whenever he thinks he can do it with safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Enough, thou hast uttered volumes.—Philo∣sophy, for the present, must, as it has often done be∣fore, give place to religion.—Wait a little, and pre∣pare to wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! the rogue is certainly some run∣away jesuit.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Where is your master, sirrah, Fabio?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Lord, poor young gentleman! it is impossible I should tell, sir: your folks cross'd in love never know where they are themselves, and how should I?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: What, is his passion very violent?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Oh, sir, monstrous!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: So much the better; your very violent love never lasts long.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: But suppose he should turn desperate, sir, and put an end to himself?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Why, then, there will be an end to all his troubles. A dead man has no need of a wife, which ought to be no small comfort to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: How can you, who are his father, talk so?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Because, I, who am his father, know him too well to be under any apprehension.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Pedro in a friar's habit.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: How, now! who let in this friar? What is your business, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I am come, son—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I am no son of your's, friend; I'm too old to be your bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Tho' not thy carnal, I am thy ghostly father, and with all humility—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Prithee, friend, let us have no abuse of terms. Not ghostly, but ghastly, thou art: carnal I believe thee to be; and as for humility, that, as well as charity, thou expectest from others; friars never keep any them∣selves.—But what do you do here, friend? What is your business? I want no confessor: I have one already, and that is one too many.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I am exceedingly sorry to find sin so inverterate in a head so grey. I come to thee, son, in all meek∣ness.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Yes, a wolf in sheep's cloathing. Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Thou dost interrogate with great haughtiness. I am Calificador to the holy office.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.STAGE: (Trembling exceedingly, and pulling off his hat.)
SP.P: Sir! an inquisitor!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: An inquisitor; and exceedingly grieved to find an aged person, whom I believed a true son of the church, a hardened sinner, and a heretic.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I beg a thousand pardons, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: And is it thus you treat our sacred fraternity? Were not the church over merciful, in long forbearance, no impious reprobate would dare thus to insult her too patient, suffering, spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I do not dare, I never did dare, offend the pious, gentle, mild, lenient, fathers of the holy inquisi∣tion. I respect, I revere, I adore—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: But tho' to succor, and to save, be her delight, she has an arm to punish.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Pray, most reverend father, hear me a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Her mercy is great, but her wrath is dreadful!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I will make any atonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Whips, racks!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: A thousand pistoles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Screws, pullies!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Two thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Gridirons!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Three thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Fires, flames, and faggots!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Four thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.STAGE: (stops, and looks with great gravity over his shoul∣der.)
SP.P: Four thousand pistoles?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Four thousand, and whatever penance your pious hand shall please to inflict.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Four thousand pistoles.—Were not the church the kindest, best, of mothers, her naughty children could not so easily appease her wrath; but she is aged and poor; she has suckled and sed them, till they are become unruly, rich, and rampant; she—Where are the four thousand pistoles?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I'll fetch them instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Stop—be not deceived; do not suppose, that blasphemy, so heinous as you have uttered, can be so easily pardoned.—But, bring the money; and, then, if I find you an obedient son in matters which I will explain to you—why, perhaps.—But, bring the money.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Oh, unfortunate day! Curst, un∣lucky adventure!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! thou hast terrisied the old gentleman half out of his wits! Thou dost it rare∣ly! But, hark thee, Pedro—concerning the four thou∣sand pistoles?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: What of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: We share.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Not so much as a marvedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Oh, yes, we must halve' em.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Don Salvador, with a bag, and overhears their conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Tho' really thou art an unconscionable rogue, Pe∣dro. Four thousand pistoles! Why zounds! thou wilt set up for a German Prince with thy share!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: My share! I have conscience enough to take care, Mr. Fabio, that you shall not touch a doit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I'll have two thousand; nay, if thou mak'st another word, I'll have three, or blow.—

DIV2.STAGE: [Don Salvador comes down, and places himself between them, looking first at one, then at the other, while they alternately steal off as he takes his eyes from them.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Stop, stop, Mr. Inquisitor, and take your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I'll call another time, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P:
A mighty fine scheme this! and I had like to have been most excellently choused. That rascal Fabio in the plot too! Who can the scoundrel be?—Oh my poor dear four thousand pistoles!—But if I lay hands on him, I'll make him pay for the panic he put me into—This must be some trick of that silly old philosopher Don Pimiento—Yes, he feels he is ridiculous himself,
and wishes to make others the same—Ha, ha, ha!—ha, ha—a fine tale he would have made on't!—He would have told it to all his birds and beasts—ha, ha, ha,—ha, ha!—He does not perceive that his cellec∣tion of owls, jack-daws, and jays, basilisks, blind worms, bulls, and baboons, are a universal satire upon himself, nay indeed upon the world.

LG.L: Of all your poetical Tuum and Meum,
Most pregnant, in simile, is a Museum:
Brutes, reptiles, birds, plants are lampoons upon life;
A Husband is Hellebore, Wormwood a Wife.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: A Vintner's a Jackall; an Author's a Grub;
Coquettes are Camelions; a Beau's a Bear's cub,
'Till barbers and taylors have lick'd him to shape,
And when metamorphos'd he is but an Ape.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Cuckoo-Courtiers are peck'd at, when too near the Throne,
And have mates who but seldom hatch eggs of their own;
Politicians, like Polypi, never can cease,
For the more you divide them the more they increase.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Led Captains are snails, who, oppos'd, still recede,
Shrink, pull in their horns, and beslime where they feed;
A Poet (a modern one) drone-like, conceals,
Debases, and lives on the honey he steals.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Some call him a Spider, whose venom, they say,
Spun into non-naturals, poisons his prey;
Man-tygers are Bailiffs, who lurk 'till they've claw'd ye,
And suck up your blood ere they mangle your body.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: A Lawyer a nondescript monster we deem;
Shark, Whale, or Leviathan's nothing to him:
His green-bag's a belly which simile mocks,
For it swallows up houses, fields, forests and flocks!

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: But he who to cite ev'ry emblem should dare,
Of Reptile and Rascal! of Bully and Bear!
While prating of Asses, Owls, Monkies and Goats,
Might cut his own fingers and other folks throats.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the apartment of Donna Zelida.
Enter Zelida and Jaquelina; Zelida holds two letters in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Pray, madam, consider: do nothing hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: No, Jaquelina, there is but one way of acting; that must be pursued, determinedly: to consider were to be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Only read the letter once again, madam, be∣fore you fend your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: It is needless; every word is imprinted in my memory. Yes, Fernando, I own thy image is engraven on my heart. To lose thee were everlasting wretchedness; but destiny, alas! is more powerful th love.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: The forest boughs, that oft have felt
The pruning Woodman's wound,
In vain accuse the exe and belt
With which they're lopt and bound:
Could I the arm of Fate direct,
Thy sorrows, Youth, should cease;
Thy days should Love and Joy protect,
Thy years should smile in peace.

DIV2.STAGE: (After the song, goes to deliver the letters to Jaquelina)—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Well, Zelida!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Ah! (Zelida in confusion endeavours to conceal the letters, by putting them in her work-bag. Don Pimiento gets a glance of them.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: You—you seem a little confused, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Lord, sir, you come so suddenly into young Ladies' rooms—My—my mistress was—she was—was—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: She was?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. (Jaquelina steals round Zelida, and slily takes the work-bag out of her, hand. As she is passing behind Don Pimiento to get to the door, he keeps his eye on her, and seizes her by the arm.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Lord, sir, let me go, I want—

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Lord, sir, let me go, I want—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don't be in a hurry, child, I wan't too.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: What, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: To see your t' other hand, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.STAGE: [Lets the work-bag drop behind her, and shews it him.]
SP.P: Well, there Sir, what would you see?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P:
Really, my dear, you understand Hocus Pocus very well; but pray move a little farther that way—a little farther. [Jaquelina keeps kicking the work-bag, behind her; he holds her with one hand, and with the other takes it up, and feels the Letters] Ha, child! Yes, they are here I be∣lieve—My friend the Philosopher was very right—Love letters here are—Rope-ladders and elopements will come next, I suppose—But we shall see— [Takes the
Letters out, reads the superscription, and starts with amaze∣ment.] How! What! 'To the most famous, most re∣nowned Master of all Sciences, Dr. Don Lilibulero! 'Indeed!, Dearest Zelida'—Begins very learnedly!—, 'Tis impossible to express the torments I this moment 'suffer—I have sent you this by my Valet, disguised pur∣posely 'to deceive your father; hope you will lend him your 'assistance'—Ah that he need not doubt of—, Consider, 'Zelida, my life is at stake! to outwit those who would 'sacrifice our happiness to their own caprice will be me∣ritorious: 'we cannot better fulfil our duty'—Most duti∣ful 'Sir!—, Life or death will be the consequence of your 'answer, to the hoping, despairing, miserable 'FERNANDO.'

And miserable may you remain!—So Madam!—So Mr, Philosopher! These are your secrets—And— [to Ja∣quelina] you! Mrs. Ten Ducats!—But he is gone to prepare the second part, I shall be sure to see him again—So, most dutiful Lady! you who are a pattern of virtue, and discretion, and meekness.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: My dearest father, hear me but for a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: You can give countenance to impostors, and join in rendering your father ridiculous to the whole world—But this, no doubt, is your answer. 'To Don Fer∣nando.'—Yes, yes;—We shall now see your dutiful sen∣timents displayed at full length; I shall here find myself painted in most beautiful colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, my dearest father, par∣don my indiscretion.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P:
Indiscretion! A most gentle term indeed for conspiring to dishonour your family, to disgrace your fa∣ther, and to render him the subject of a footman's ballad in every twopenny taphouse—But we shall see, we shall see. (Opens the letter and reads.), I am ashamed of 'mysel,—Well you may, indeed!—I am ashamed 'of myself when I find my conduct has been such, 'Fernando, as could authorize your present proceed∣ings, '—How, how!—, I must be the most unduti∣ful, 'the worst of children, could I, any way, wilfully 'contribute to see my father so indecenty imposed upon,— (Looks at Zelida.) My girl! my child!—When
'authorized by my father, I did not scruple to confess 'my affection for you, nor do I, still, to own that his 'consent to our union would, perhaps, give me as much 'pleasure as you; but, without his consent, I never will 'be your's,—Zelida!—, I cannot pardon myself for 'having received your letter without his knowledge; and 'I assure you, no power on earth shall ever make me 'your's, if, after the receipt of this, you continue to 'impose on him by means which, tho' perhaps not so 'considered by you, are degrading and insulting.,' [Don Pimiento weeps aloud, and lets the letter fall out of his hands.] Zelida!—You are a good girl, Zelida! A good girl!—But that damn'd rascal, that Philosopher, that footman, that scoundrel—Diego— [Don Pimiento keeps weeping in the midst of his extreme anger.]

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: I feel, sir, you have been very improperly treated; but let me conjure you to consider that—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Consider! I'll be revenged!

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: But, sir, if you would but remember a little philosophy—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Damn philosophy! I'll be revenged— [Still weeping.]. Diego!—Guilermo!—

DIV2.P: Get me a blanket, a strong one, a new one, never worn.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Have mercy, sir, upon the poor fellow; he is but a footman. It will degrade you to—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Will it?—But, if it degrades me, it shall elevate him—And tho' you are a good girl, Zelida, you are a little pitiful, and therefore, that neither you nor your ten ducat waiting-woman may convey any intelli∣gence to the rascal, I must keep you under lock and key a little while.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Let me know but what your will is, sir, and, whatever violence it may do my own feelings, you my honor it shall be obeyed.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I could?trust you, Zelida—Nay, I will trust you—but as for you—

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Oh lord, sir, I'll give you my honour too, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Zel.
SP.P: Sir, I pledge my word she shall not stir out of my apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Do you, Zelida? Well, I will not doubt hour word; you are a good girl, Zelida, a good girl! [To Jaquelina.] You, perhaps, would like to be magne∣tized once more—A rascal! with his mesmerites and parachutes—Where the devil could the fellow pick up all that?—Ha! [The rest of this speech, aside.] As sure as fate—Don Salvador is at the bottom of this!—It is a scheme to make a fool of a philosopher!—The old are to laugh and be laugh'd at!—It must be so—I'll send him a challenge. Employ his rascally agents to make a fool of me!—I'll send him a challenge—Instantly!—A challenge!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Thus then are all my expectations blight∣ed, and such, and so transitory, are human joys!

LG.L: Hope points to happiness, and, smiling,
Shews us where the Phantom lies;
But, the grasping hand beguiling,
From the touch it starts and flies.
Thus, the butterfly the boy
With chacing wearied is, and cross'd;
Thus, when he'd seizeth' expected joy,
Tow'rds heaven it rises and is lost

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: So our philosopher is in a pretty way! Don Pimiento won't leave him a whole bone.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Zel.
SP.P: No; tho' My father is passionate, he is na∣turally merciful, and will rather frighten than hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: 'Pshaw! madam, I am sure he will half murder him. But you mean to let me go and tell Don Fernando what has happened.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Zel.
SP.P: You shall not stir: I am determin'd to obey my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: And wilfully make yourself and Don Fernando miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Not wilfully; I have no choice: if it de∣pended upon me, his happiness should be the business and delight of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: If? Why lord, madam, it does depend on you, and nobody but you. A pretty thing, indeed—

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Silence, Jaquelina: I'll have no improper liberties taken with my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Why then, madam, your father should not take improper liberties with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: I have only to do my duty, and hope for the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: Hope, madam! Why, don't you know your father's temper? And didn't you hear him pledge his word and honour to Don Velasco?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: I did—Alas! there is no hope! Let con∣scious rectitude, then, and resignation be my support.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Zel
SP.L: When passion racks the virgin' heart,
Not ev'n allow'd to hope;
From duty fearful to depart,
What can she do?

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.L: Elope.
I'd never sit so pale and wan,
I'd never pine and mope;
I'd break from bondage, take the man,
And light as air elope.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Zel.
SP.L: I'll patient sit so pale and wan,
I'll patient pine and mope;
A duteous child sure never can,
No—never will, elope.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isabel, walking about in extreme anxiety, and speaking only at intervals.
SP.P: YES—yes, yes, I deserve it—the punishment is just—I have lost him for ever, and with him, for ever lost my tranquillity. Will Laura never return?—By what strange infaturation am I governed?—To be con∣scious of one's folly!—of one's extreme absurdity, even at the very moment when it is most predomi∣nant!—to feel it strengthen in proportion as one feels its destructive tendency!—Can this be?—Yes, it is, it is!— (Rings.)Enter a Footman. It not Laura come back yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Possessed by the tormenting spirit of silly female vanity—of capricious pride—My heart and my tongue in continual contradiction—my understanding and self-love at eternal warfare—ever endeavoring to humble, and render the man I loved, abject; yet, cer∣tain to despise him, had he become so. Where can this girl be?—He'll perceive she is sent by my orders, and will despise me for my meanness. (rings.)Enter a Footman. Do you hear any thing of Laura yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Run, see if you can meet her, and tell her to make haste.
