SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Which way, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Towards Don—heavens! am I going to betray my weaknefs, even to my very footman?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Where, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: No where.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Don Fabricio's, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: So! my passions make me the sport of my very servants!—What do you stand for?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Go, go, go.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Where, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: No where. (pettishly.) [Exit Foot∣man, shrugging up his shoulders. Laughed at—despis'd—tortured.—

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Where have you been all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Lord, madam! I have runn'd myself off my legs.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Have you seen Fabricio?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Oh yes, madam, I have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Tell me instantly what he says.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Says, madam?—I never heard a man talk so, and look so, in my life. He complains, and laughs, and sighs, and swears, and prays, and weeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I never saw any poor gentleman in such a tak∣ing. He calls you an angel, and a coquette, and his de∣light, and his torment, and his dear, and his devil; and vows he shall die if you are not his; and swears he'll never see you more.—He rav'd so, I declare he frighted me.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: So, he does not talk of coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: He said, madam, he knew very well, you wanted him to come back.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Sure you did not tell him that I sent you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Oh, no, madam; you know how strictly you charged me not.—And so he swore, he would rather die a thousand times; and yet, madam, I do believe if he had but thought as how you had sent me, he would have come directly; for he ast me, over and over, whether you sent me, or if you wanted to see him; and I vowed, and purtested, I came of my own head.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Stupid wretch! why did you do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why, lord, madam, did not you bid me?—I did slip out a word or two, and then he was going to come all in a hurry, and then I was oblig'd to swear, and declare, that you knew nothing of the matter; and then he began (to utter such dreadful oaths! I declare I was sca∣rified.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Idiot!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why, lord, madam, I did not know what to do; I am sure, I would have told him, with all my heart, what a condition you were in, if I dar'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Condition!—Oh, pride, pride!—How mean! how abject!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: And so, madam, he said at last, he should go and take a walk on the Prado; and so, madam, I do believe, that was as much as to say, that, if you wanted him, there you might find him.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Wanted him!—This is insup∣portable!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: And so, madam, if I might advise—

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why, madam, I am certain—

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: Hold your tongue I say—My present torments are not to be endured—yes, I deserve every hu∣miliation that can be inflicted on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P:
Well, to be sure, she is in a strange twittera∣tion—I know she is in fifty minds now—she does not know whether she should go or stay, or be angry of sorry, or humble, or obstinate, or what—I can't say but I do hope he'll bring her proud stomach down. Such strange fancies and fangles, and airs, and flights, and I will, and I won't—but lord, 'tis the way of all these fine ladies. Because they have not one single thing on earth to cross them, they are always racking their brains to torment
themselves—But some folks are fortunate, and some folks are misfortunate.

LG.L: Not all poor Laura's truth and love
Can her too faithless Sancho move!
Alas! poor Laura, forlorn, alone,
Thy Love has left thee here to moan!
Were thy poor bosom from love and from Sancho free,
Couldst thou forget both his fondness and perfidy,
Or, did he know how to value thy constancy,
Oh! what a happy young maiden would Laura be!
Did he not smile on another, neglecting thee,
Did he not treat with disdain thy integrity,
Did he remember the oaths he has sworn to thee,
Oh! what a happy young maiden would Laura be!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Fabricio, walks about, melancholy and uneasy, Pedro following.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Here he is—If I am not mistaken, love, pride, and obstinacy are each tormenting him by turns—Now to try whether I cannot incline the balance in favor of love— (approaches to Fabricio) Sir! young gentleman! may I crave your ear for a moment?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Well, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Your name is Don Fabricio, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: And what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: You must understand Sir, there has been a evere combat, between my honour and my penchant.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Your—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: And as you, Sir, were the subject of contention, is for that reason I intreat a hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: You must have observed, Sir, there are certain pleasing countenances that captivate the moment they are seen.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Your phisiognomy, Sir, has that happy engag∣ing cast. I was struck when I beheld it, and could not help instantly wishing myself an appendage to so placid, so mild, so sweet a nobleman, for noble you certainly are.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I would advise you, friend, to go on with your story, or get out of my reach, lest I should con∣vince you, I am not quite so mild, and so placid, as your thetorical flourishes pretend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ah no, Sir, I am in perfect security.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Are you? (Seems going to strike him, and Pedro bows and looks in his face with a smile of bumble im∣pudence. Fabricio can't forbear laughing) This is a strange, odd, impudent fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Were you not the amiable person I have been describing, I could never reconcile my present proceed∣ing to my conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Damn your conscience, and your present proceeding! What's your business?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I knew you had the manners of a nobleman! With what a grace you swear! so natural— (Observes Fabricio driven beyond his patience) I do not wonder at Donna Isabel's passion for you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Donna Isabel! What do you know of Donna Isabel?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: My name is Pedro, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Confound the fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I am servant to Don Fernando, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: But Donna Isabel—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Will soon be married to my master, Sir, if you don't prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: In revenge—Misunderstandings on all sides! Donna Isabel believes you false; my master supposes you in love with Donna Zelida; and they have agreed to be married, with a charitable hope you will hang yourself for vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Impossible.

P.HI: Now as I knew this would make four true lov∣ers miserable, my penchant for you, Sir, has vanquished the obstacles my honour raised to the betraying of my master's secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Can this be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Put me to my oath—Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Ungrateful, false, Isabel!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, you mistake the matter. 'Tis excess of love, and not inconstancy. Offer her your hand, she won't refuse; lead her to church, and thus wipe off your old score of troubles, and begin a new one.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: No—I am determined I'll go to the Prado—I will not eternally bend thus to a capricious temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I am not master of myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Kind Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: I know not what to resolve.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Permit me to inform you, gentle Sir, I feel an∣other very strong internal struggle, at this very moment, between my poverty and my pride.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: What next?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Knowing your generosity, my poverty would fain persuade me to accept the purse you are going to pre∣sent me; but my pride, dreading to be thought selfish, is treating my poor poverty with that contempt with which pride always treats poverty.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Here, sirrah, here is money for you; but ob∣serve, if I find you have been imposing upon me—

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I understand the conditions, Sir, and my shoul∣ders shall be forth coming—They are ostensible.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Cruel, unjust Isabel!

LG.L: The wayward tongue, fond Love repelling,
The frown-fraught brow, the scorn-taught eye,
Can these, which jealous fraud imply,
In such an angel form find dwelling?
Yes! these extremes of contrast dwell
In thee, too lovely Isabel!

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Can taunts, and scoffs, and wild caprices,
Sully those lips, by Venus giv'n,
The lover's fancied, hop'd-for heaven
Of sweets, and smiles, and balmy kisses?
Yes! such extremes of contrast dwell
In thee, too lovely Isabel!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: There he goes—the direct road to her house, de∣termining all the way he won't go near her.—Really, Mr. Cupid, you are a droll little fellow.

LG.L: Cupid, sure, of cunning knaves,
Is the chief, sir.!
All his subjects are but slaves,
To their grief, sir;
A slippery, frippery, foolish band;
For whim, and gold,
Bought and sold;
By this mad, blind, boy trepann'd,:
In his pound,
When they're found,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the thief, sir!

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Did you see him huff and ding,
When he's fallen!
Whimper, caper, curse, and sing,
Talk of killing!
Whistle, nestle, come and go;
Fume, and fret,
His will to get;
Meaning yes, and answering no;
Till, at last,
The frolic past,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the villain!

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: When a maid is young and coy,
And the lover
Symptoms of a bashful boy
Should discover;
He'll loiter, titter, hide, and seek;
Nudge, and dodge,
And rap, and tap;
If pursu'd, will squeal, and squeak:
But if the boy
Prove too coy,
Why then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh, the rover!

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: When a youth is warm and bold,
Strong, unruly,
And the maiden fair, but cold,
Then why, truly,
Swearing, tearing, sighing, dying,
Silly, sad,
Sullen, mad,
Wearied with so much denying,
Death's the word!
Draws his sword,
But then—fa, la, la, la,
Oh! the bully!

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: All his antics pray relate,
They who can, sir:
Young and old and small and great
To trepan, sir!
How he'll juggle, jeer, cajole,
Plague and please,
Entice and teize,
'Till they're under his controul,
How his speech
Will men bewitch,
And then—Fa, la, la, la,
The Necromancer!

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the house of Don Salvador.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Be under no apprehension, sir; love will recon∣cile Don Fabricio, and Donma Isabel: we may still find some means of gaining Don Salvador's consent; and as for Don Pimiento, I believe the greatest Philosopher liv∣ing could not have passed upon him better.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But is it not strange I have not received any answer from Zelida! I begin to be upon the rack.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Jaquelina perhaps could not find any opportu∣nity to slip out, fir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Here, take this, return to Don Pimiento's, and convey, it as before; but do not come away, if possible, without bringing me an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Never fear, sir, you shall soon receive a good account of me—the old Don will rejoice to see me again.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Salvador, on the opposite side.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Was there ever such an old fool! He's mad, there's no doubt but he is mad!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What's the matter, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Matter, sir! perhaps you can tell me what's the matter, sir. Do you know any thing of any pre∣tended Philosopher?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Sir! Philosopher!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: That old, unaccountable ape, Don Pimiento, sends me word he'll toss my Philosopher in a blanket, and cut my throat.—He has sent me a challenge, here! in direct terms!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: A challenge, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: But I'll cool him, I'll chastise his insolence: he shall never stick pin thro' butterfly more.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Why, surely sir, you won't think of fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: What! receive a challenge, and from a tot∣tering skin of parchment, full of inflammable air! but I'll drill him, I'll make it whiz out.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Lost and undone! Where can this Fabio be?—Don Pimiento will murder Pedro, and I am more certain of losing Zelida now than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: He pretend to send a challenge!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: But, sir, tho' he has no more temper and understanding, I hope you will not so forget your charac∣ter, station and age.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I want none of your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, my dear father, mode∣rate your anger!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I want none of your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Consider, sir, that my happiness depends upon the possession of Zelida.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Then it has a very slender dependence in∣deed, for she never shall be your's, she never can be your's, I being sully determined to cut her father's throat. Don't follow me; keep back.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Distraction! What is to be done? Fabio!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Run, instantly, and try to overtake Pedro. (recollecting himself) No, no; send somebody else after Pedro, and do you watch my father; he's gone with an intent to fight Don Pimiento. Think, invent some means of keeping them asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Me invent! lord, sir, I am an animal of in∣stinct, and—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Don't stand prating, sir, fly, follow my fa∣ther; watch him, and if you can find no other means of preventing this ridiculous duel, raise the neighbourhood.— [Exit Fabio.]—Every thing conspires to overwhelm me with vexation and despair. Pedro detected, the breach between our fathers widened, and Fabricio's ir∣reconcilable quarrel with his mistress.—Obstacles and mischiess accumulate.—Oh, my Zelida! my angel! my life! either I am thine, or I am nothing!

LG.L: Oh love, thou powerful, pleasing, pain!
The heart that owns thy mighty sway
Shall ne'er recover peace again,
But waste in sighs the chearful day.
Can words describe my countless fears;
While on the rack of doubt I lie;
While doom'd to pass my time in tears,
Condemn'd without complaint to die?
In vain I wish for lost repose;
In vain would absence bring relies
Still love within my bosom, glows,
And death, alone, can calm my grief.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the Museum of Don Pimiento.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: My master will be with you immediately, sir; he desired me to tell you, he is making preparations for a phi∣losophical experiment, but that—Oh, here he comes.—
SP.STAGE: Pedro and Don Pimiento, bowing; the latter struggling to conceal his passion 'till he breaks out at opening the letter.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: This quick return, sir, is exceedingly kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I assure you, sir, I am superlatively glad to see you; as it will give me infinite pleasure to treat you as your high merit deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Pray, sir—you confound me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: May I take the liberty to ask, most sage sir, whether you have prepared your second letter to the very learned Doctor Don Lilibulero?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh, yes, sir, I have it, here it is.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: And as curious, no doubt, as the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh! scientific! abstruse!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: And the philosopher is by this time half made a fool of?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: That, sir, nature made him.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Humph! [Turns aside grinding his teeth.]—Well, sir, shall I take this letter and give it to my maid? For, as she delivered the last, she will be the less liable to make any mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: True, sir; that is a most philosophic, and just remark.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: You send this without the ducats?

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Yes, fir, yes; but I'll take care the young wo∣man shall be fewarded hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I will be still more generous, sir; for I will take care that you shall be rewarded at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don't be impatient; stand where you are, young man; you shall be magnetised;—Here, rascals! where are you all?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter four servants, who lay hold of Pedro.
DIV2.P: Now, Mr. Philosopher, tho' you have visited all regions, known, and unknown—, I'll try how you like the upper regions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, sir, have some mercy; do but listen to me, and you shall hear.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: As many lies as I please. You, I say, shall fly—fly—without a balloon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Pray, gentle∣men, do you have pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Consider, I am a fellow servant.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Let' em consider, if they dare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Is there no forbearance?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: No mitigation?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Come, come; away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Zel.
SP.P: Fly! fly! my dear father—save yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Why, how now! what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Zel.
SP.P: Archers! Alguazils!—Mercy!—'Tis too late!—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: How, now, sir; who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: Who, am I, sir? My name is Josepho Ribeiro; and my office is that of his Majesty's Alguazil.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: And, pray, sir, what business have you in my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: I come, sir, by order of the Supreme Council, to inform you, that you have lost your cause with the Count de Cordova; and that you are condemn'd to pay five thousand pistoles; which, by order of the said Count, and Court, I am now come to demand immediate payment of, without hindrance, let, or, delay; or, to take your person into custody.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Confusion! Damnation! Five thousand pistoles![At the entrance of the Alguazil, the servants, who hold Pedro, stand amazed; and Pedro, after observing what passes, with surprize, escapes.] It is impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: Sir, if you won't take my word, here's my autho∣rity.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Ruin, and distraction!

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: My orders, sir, are precise, and strict. You know the power of the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I have here, indeed, too fatal a proof of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: Therefore, sir, either, deliver me the five thou∣sand pistoles, or, deliver your body into the keeping of these four worthy gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Five thousand pistoles is a sum not to be paid thus instantaneously.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: I have told you what are my orders, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Surely, sir, you can de∣lay a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P:
Why, sir, as you seem a gentleman of understanding, I will do every thing in my
power to oblige you. However sir, I can assure you, my orders are very severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, stay but till my father's friends can be informed of his missortune, and, I will for er bless and pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don't terrify yourself, my child—Tho' my enemy be powerful and proud, he shall find I am not to∣tally deserted.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: I hope not, yet doubt is dreadful.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But it makes certainty more sweet.

SP.SPEAKER: Zel.
SP.P: It does! it does!
SP.STAGE: [Exeunt Don Pimiento, Alguazil and Archers; manet Zelida.]

DIV1.HEAD: SONG.
DIV1.L: When o'er the wold, the heedless lamb
Hath, 'till the dusky twilight, stray'd;
His simple plaints cry "here I am!
"Of night and solitude afraid."
But if, far off, his dam he hears,
Ecchoing, oft, the mournful bleat,
He runs, and stops, and hopes, and sears,
And bounds with pleasure! when they meet.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the outside of Don Pimiento's House.
Enter Pedro from the house, frighten'd.
DIV2.P: Oof!—I have escaped by miracle!—Oh that damn'd blanket!—Our affairs too, worse than ever!—And the devil to pay within!—Where is my unfortunate master?—I must endeavour to find him, and inform him of all his miseries.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Salvador looking at his watch.
DIV2.P: I am a quarter before my time—I warrant I teach you to invite me to put on my sword and take private walks with you, my testy philosopher.
DIV2.STAGE: Walks up to the back of the stage.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: I can see by his countenance our old Don is de∣termin'd to fight—I wish I could find, some means to—Ha! I've a thought! If I can but succeed, it will be a master-stroke!—I'll venture.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.STAGE: [Coming down the stage looking at his watch.]
SP.P: He is willing not to come before his time; but he is right to defer his execution as long as possible.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Fabio, sobbing and pretending to weep, not grotesquely, but as naturally as possible.
DIV2.P: How now, sir, what is the matter with you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Oh my poor master! Poor Don Fernando!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: What, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Dead, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Dying—Mortally wounded, sir— [Sobbing.] The sur-ur-urgeon says, sir, the sword of Don Fabri-i∣cio has passed in a ri-ight line thro' the left lobe of his lungs, and that it's im-im-im-impossible he can live for a quarter of an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Where—where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: He li-ies with his handkerchief stuff'd in his side, and his ha-a-and over his mouth, holding in his breath, that it may-ayn't depart till you have given him your blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Ah! where is he? where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: This way, sir, under the walls of the Buen Re∣tiro Palace. [Going, turns round and stops.] My heart bleeds to think of the tor-or-ortures he this mo-o-oment endures.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: My poor-oor-oor Fernando!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Bless me, sir! What's the matter!

SP.SPEAKER: Fab.
SP.P: Avaunt, Satan—Take care, sir,—his ghost is come to haunt you.
SP.STAGE: [Don Salvador perceives the trick that has been play'd him, and his countenance changes from sorrow to anger. Fabio winks, and endeavours to make Fernando understand him.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I'll haunt you, rascal!

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Pedro—[Takes Fernando aside, and whispers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Alguazils and Archers!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Fact, I assure you, sir; they are now in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Madness and distraction! Were there not impediments enough before to my happiness! Follow me.

DIV2.STAGE: [Exeunt Fernando and Pedro into the house.]

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I'll teach you to play your tricks upon me— [Sees Fernando entering Pimiento's house, and calls.] Harkye, sir! Fernando!—Fernando, I say!—Where the devil are you going, sirrah?—He won't hear—A headlong!—I'll fetch him out! I'll—

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to the inside of the House.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: If you will hear what I have to say, I am cer∣tain you will not think of pursuing this quarrel further; at least not at this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Sir, I tell you I am come with a resolution to cut his throat; and the sayings of neither you, nor Seneca, nor all the wise men that ever existed, could make the least impression on me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: What, sir, would you insult an enemy in distress?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: In distress!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Don Pimiento is now, sir, in the hands of Archers, arrested at the suit of the Count de Cordova, for five thousand pistoles.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: How, how? Which way could Don Pimiento owe the Count de Cordova five thousand pistoles?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: By decree of the Supreme Council, he has lost his cause. Justice was on the side of Don Pimiento, but power on the side of his adversary; and, unfortunate∣ly for Spain, power is here superior to Justice.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Zelida, in tears, followed by Don Pimiento, Alguazil and Archers.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: For mercy's sake, sir, do not hurry my father away thus. Wait till he can send for his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: We have shewn you our orders, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal. (whispers Fernando, and gives him a key)
SP.P: Do you hear, sir? fly.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Dry your tears, Zelida, you are a good child.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: You seem in haste, Mr. Alguazil: Where are you going to take this gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: To prison, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don Salvador! What, sir, are you come to infult me at such a time as this?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Insult you, sir? Pray, sir, when did you know me insult any gentleman in distress?—And pray, Mr. Alguazil, what is your reason for taking Don Pimi∣ento to prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: I am so commanded, sir, because he can't pay his debts.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Can't he?—but if he can't, I can, and I command you to let him remain in his own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don Salvador—What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: What do I mean!—Are not you a gentle∣man, and a Spaniard, Don Pimiento?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Yes, I have that honor, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P:
Then how dare you ask me, what I mean, when I see a person of that description oppress'd, and
have the power to succour him?—What do you think I can mean?—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.STAGE: (Greatly moved, and taking Don Salvador by the hand.)
SP.P: Don Salvador, you—you are a gentleman—a true Castilian—and I revere you—and I am sorry I quarrell'd with you—but I can't accept your favor.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: No! Why then you are a proud—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: No, it is not pride; but my honor is pledg's to Don Velasco, and the union of our children is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: I perceive, Don Pimiento, you are determined I shall cut your throat. Do you think I come like a Usurer, with my money in one hand, and my clauses and conditions in the other, Cent. per Cent. in my own favor?

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Oh, sir! I shall love and revere you as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don Salvador, I am sorry?I quarrell'd with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: You are the noblest, the best of men.

SP.SPEAKER: Alg.
SP.P: Well, but gentlement—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Oh! what your hurry is not over yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Fer.
SP.P: Sir, the mo∣ney is below.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Please to walk down, sir, with this young gentleman, and he will see you satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Now, Don Pi∣miento, if you think I have injured you, I am ready to give you satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Don Salvador, I feel the generous and no∣ble manner of your proceeding. You have rescued me from the power of a malignant and, mean enemy, and, without drawing your sword, have vanquish'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P:
I believe, Don Pimiento, we have both been to blame. However, for my own part, I'll give you my promise never to dispute about things I don't understand any more, nor ever more laugh at philosophy, especially in your presence.—He that does a gentleman a pecuniary favor, and afterwards takes improper liberties with him,
shews he meanly expended his money to purchase a slave, and not generously to acquire a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Joy, joy, my Zelida!—Permit me, Don Pi∣miento, to introduce my friends.

DIV2.STAGE: (Don Pimiento bows assent, and Fernando in∣troduces Don Fabricio, and Isabel. They salute the company.)

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Give me leave, Donna Zelida, to present this lady to you, who is now the better part of myself.—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: Yes, sir. I hope you will excuse—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Excuse—sir, I'll—I'll—Zelida!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: This is most fortunate!

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Isa.
SP.P: I will own to you, Donna Zelida, that, half an hour ago, I considered you as the most dangerous person in the world, perhaps as my enemy; I shall now be proud of your friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Donna Zel.
SP.P: Dear madam, you give me life and hap∣pineis!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: Here, Don Fernando, tho' there is not a better girl in all Spain, no, nor in all the universe, than my Zelida, I am certain you will deserve her.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.STAGE: (Receives her hand and kisses it with rapture.)
SP.P: I will at least endeavour to do so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: But, pray, give me leave to ask, young gentleman, is not that the Philosopher?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: I am sorry, and ashamed.—But, indeed, sir, it was a trick of the sellow's own invention.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Oh, yes, sir! don't rob me of the honor of the invention.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Silence, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Ah! thus are men of genius treated by the Great, when they no longer stand in need of their assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: And Don Salvador—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: Knew nothing of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Pimi.
SP.P: I ask your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Sal.
SP.P: And the inquisitor! Ah, rascal! It's well I happen to be in a very good humor.—But keep out of my way, the first time thou see'st me angry.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fab.
SP.P: The rogue play'd me a trick among the rest; but he did me a favor; and has so ready a wit that he de∣serves to be rewarded, as well as pardoned.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Gentlemen are so apt to forget their promises—otherwise Don Fernando is under a promise to make my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: That must depend upon your behavior.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Depend, depend.—I observe your people in power are always exceedingly anxious to keep a man of talents in a state of dependance. They feel they have robb'd him of his birthright, and even grudge him his poor mess of potage.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Fer.
SP.P: Well, sir; you shall find a gentleman, for once, who will keep his promise.—You have merit, and I should ill deserve the happiness I now enjoy, were I to let merit languish, neglected, and without its reward.

SP.SPEAKER: PEDRO.
SP.L: To troubles, then, a truce;
With the berry berry's juice
We'll be merry merry, while we may:
For, it's very very true,
He looks very very blue,
Who died only yesterday!

SP.SPEAKER: ZELIDA and ISABEL.
SP.L: Now faith and affection, united, agree;
Their efforts have worthily won us;

SP.SPEAKER: FERNANDO and ZELIDA.
SP.L: And the Loves and the Graces, in concert, decree,
To shower down happiness on us.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus,
SP.P: To troubles, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Don SALVADOR.
SP.L: In mirth let us vie! let the wine sparkle high!
O'er Old Time let us King it and Queen it!

SP.SPEAKER: Don PIMIENTO.
SP.L: For while the heart glow,
And with joy overflows,
We live millions of years in a minute!

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.P: To troubles then a truce, &c.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE Passages between inverted Commas, are necessarily omitted in Represen∣tation. The third Song in the third Act s written by a Friend of the Author's, and wo others have before appeared in Print.
